claim: If tiger sharks stop swimming, nothing in particular happens to them.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, require continuous swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen extraction; stopping would lead to suffocation.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, require continuous swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen extraction; stopping would lead to suffocation.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor in areas with strong currents, which may provide passive ventilation.
Such resting behavior is extremely rare and has only been documented in specific locations with unique hydrodynamic conditions.
Juvenile tiger sharks may be able to use buccal pumping (active gill ventilation) as a temporary alternative to ram ventilation.
Buccal pumping in tiger sharks is energetically inefficient and cannot sustain them for extended periods.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks rely on swimming to maintain buoyancy and stability in the water; ceasing movement would disrupt their ability to stay afloat.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks rely on swimming to maintain buoyancy and stability in the water; ceasing movement would disrupt their ability to stay afloat.
Some shark species, including tiger sharks, can use buccal pumping to force water over their gills while stationary, reducing the need for constant swimming.
Buccal pumping is energetically costly and inefficient compared to ram ventilation, making it unsustainable for tiger sharks for extended periods.
Tiger sharks have been observed resting motionless on the ocean floor in certain environments, suggesting they can survive without continuous swimming.
Such resting behavior is rare and typically occurs in shallow, oxygen-rich waters, not representative of their typical pelagic habitat.

supporting.text: Movement is essential for tiger sharks to hunt and forage; stopping swimming would impair their ability to catch prey and obtain nutrients.

attacks.text: Movement is essential for tiger sharks to hunt and forage; stopping swimming would impair their ability to catch prey and obtain nutrients.
Tiger sharks can survive for extended periods without actively swimming by using buccal pumping to force water over their gills, allowing them to rest.
Buccal pumping is energetically costly and less efficient than ram ventilation, so prolonged inactivity would still lead to reduced hunting efficiency and potential starvation.
Tiger sharks are opportunistic scavengers and can feed on carcasses or slow-moving prey without continuous swimming.
Scavenging opportunities are unreliable and insufficient to meet the metabolic demands of an adult tiger shark consistently.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks' metabolic processes depend on continuous swimming to sustain circulation and respiration; stopping would cause physiological stress or death.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks' metabolic processes depend on continuous swimming to sustain circulation and respiration; stopping would cause physiological stress or death.
Some shark species, like nurse sharks, can actively pump water over their gills and do not require constant swimming to respire.
Tiger sharks are obligate ram ventilators, unlike nurse sharks, and cannot actively pump water over their gills.
Tiger sharks may occasionally rest on the ocean floor in areas with strong currents that passively provide sufficient water flow over their gills.
Such resting behavior is rarely observed and likely unsustainable for extended periods due to insufficient oxygenation.
